TopicTitle: Parts are unlocked by buying them with science in an online auction

Articles.Content:
Since some parts are pretty valuable for construction, such as the cubic octogonal strut, players will purchase two or three nodes in advance to acquire them early.

What if the price of unlocking a part in the game was determined by a free market?

Let a server release one of each part per n seconds, and hold a brief online auction to determine which connected player gets to unlock that part in their game. They must bid science they earned in-game, and pay the bid if they win.

The auction rate is adapted to meet average demand for parts in general.

Edited May 3, 2014 by nhnifong
What happens when I'm playing offline? For that matter, what benefit to gameplay does this provide (I can't see any)?

Terrible idea. It means that people will be denied access to parts because they are essential for ship design. The first thing I'd expect to see is a huge bottleneck for decouplers - a part which is currently one of the first you unlock for very cheap, and for good reason.

And it also ties the game to a server, which can go down or be shut down permanently, thereby crippling your game.
Why the crap would you crowbar a server in a single player game?

In a multiplayer game this might work but not in single player.

Especially in single player this would put new, inexperienced players at a huge disadvantage. Experienced players just starting over for fun know how to grind science even without those 'vital' parts and have more science points to spend, inflating the prices for the people that REALLY need the parts.
